title: Goldman Posts Lower Profit in Mixed Quarter for Wall Street; Wall Street bank's profit fell 42% in first quarter; earnings beat analyst expectations
text:
Revenue was down 27% to $12.93 billion. That beat the $11.86 billion expected by analysts.

The firm's investment bankers took in $2.41 billion in fees, 36% lower than a year ago. Far fewer companies went public in a market that endured volatile stock, bond and commodity prices. The quarter also included the highest inflation in decades and the war in Ukraine.

The bank reported a 4% increase in trading revenue to $7.87 billion.

Goldman shares closed Wednesday at $321.97, down 16% for the year. They were up about 2% in premarket trading Thursday.

Goldman earned $1.13 billion in fees from advising on mergers and acquisitions, up 1% from a year ago. Revenue from underwriting initial public offerings and other stock offerings fell 83% to $261 million.

Goldman's Main Street businesses fared better. Revenue in the consumer and wealth-management division rose 21% to $2.1 billion, or about 16% of the firm's first-quarter revenue. The unit includes Goldman's Marcus consumer bank and the team serving wealthy clients.

The bank last month closed its acquisition of specialty lender GreenSky Inc., which arranges loans for big one-time purchases such as home renovation projects.

Compensation expenses fell 32% to $4.08 billion. Total operating expenses were $7.71 billion, down 18% from the same period last year.

The bank's return on equity, a measure of how profitably it uses shareholders' money, was 15% on an annualized basis.
